sources.title: The Cook’s Revenge (1900) Directed By Georges Méliès
sources.description: The Cook’s Revenge (1900) 'La vengeance du gâte-sauce' Director: Georges Méliès The Cook's Revenge (French: La Vengeance du gâte-sauce) is a 1900 French silent trick film by Georges Méliès. Production and survival: Méliès himself plays the cook, one of his many roles in which he loses his head or has several duplicate heads. The special effects are created with substitution splices and multiple exposures on a black background. The Cook's Revenge was released by Méliès's Star Film Company and is numbered 243 in its catalogues.Long presumed lost, a print of the film was eventually rediscovered in Manosque by the son of a fairground exhibitor, and sold to Méliès's granddaughter, Madeleine Malthête-Méliès.

metadata.Plot: In the heart of a busy and immaculate kitchen, the amorous advances of a lascivious cook to a deliciously fresh waitress cause a small disaster, as the startled woman drops the entire stack of porcelain dishes she was carrying onto the floor. To escape the manager's wrath, the naughty cook hides in a wooden cupboard; however, when he unwisely sticks his head out, a forceful and loud push against the door leads to an immediate and unforeseen punishment. But, is this truly the end?
